[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/pruner/ledger_pruner/mod.rs] [Function: prune()] [Disk I/O saturation] Can repeated calls to prune() with small max_versions values at line 62 cause excessive disk I/O thrashing, degrading validator performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/pruner/ledger_pruner/mod.rs] [Function: prune()] [CPU exhaustion] The par_iter() at line 79 spawns threads for each sub-pruner (7 pruners at lines 176-184). Can this exhaust CPU resources if called repeatedly or concurrently? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/pruner/ledger_pruner/mod.rs] [Function: prune()] [Progress update overhead] Is record_progress() at line 87 called too frequently? If max_versions is small, can excessive progress updates cause contention on the AtomicVersion? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/pruner/ledger_pruner/mod.rs] [Function: prune()] [Version underflow] If progress() at line 63 returns 0 and target_version is also 0, can the while loop at line 66 exhibit undefined behavior or skip necessary initialization? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/pruner/ledger_pruner/mod.rs] [Function: prune()] [Zero max_versions] What happens if max_versions=0 is passed to prune() at line 62? Will line 68 cause current_batch_target_version = progress, creating an infinite loop at line 66? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/pruner/ledger_pruner/mod.rs] [Function: prune()] [Progress equals target] If progress == target_version at line 66, the loop correctly exits. But if an attacker manipulates this via race conditions, can it skip necessary pruning work? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/pruner/ledger_pruner/mod.rs] [Function: target_version()] [Uninitialized read] If target_version() at line 105 is called before set_target_version(), what value is returned? Can this cause unexpected pruning behavior if default is non-zero? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/pruner/ledger_pruner/mod.rs] [Function: prune()] [Off-by-one] At line 68, is current_batch_target_version inclusive or exclusive? Can off-by-one errors cause the last version in a range to not be pruned or be pruned twice? (Medium)
